chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Suspected transient ischaemic attack
chapter.summary: Covers the management in primary care of people who present with a history of neurological symptoms that have resolved within 24 hours and suggest TIA.

Scenario: Management of long term complications of stroke

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected TIA?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the person has had a suspected TIA within the last week:
    • Give aspirin 300 mg immediately (with proton pump inhibitor cover where appropriate) and arrange urgent assessment (within 24 hours) by a specialist stroke physician unless:
      • They have a bleeding disorder or are taking an anticoagulant as haemorrhage requires exclusion — arrange immediate admission for urgent assessment and imaging.
      • They are taking low-dose aspirin regularly — continue the current dose of aspirin until reviewed by a specialist.
      • Aspirin is contraindicated — discuss management urgently with the specialist team.
    • Be aware that a person may have ongoing focal neurological deficits despite a negative Fast test and such people must be managed as acute stroke rather than TIA.
    • Discuss the need for admission or observation urgently with a stroke specialist if the person:
      • Has had more than one suspected TIA (sometimes known as crescendo TIA).
      • Has a suspected cardioembolic source or severe carotid stenosis.
      • May be unable to attend for urgent review or lacks a reliable observer at home to contact emergency services if further symptoms occur.
  • If the person has had a suspected TIA which occurred more than a week previously:
    • Refer for specialist assessment as soon as possible within 7 days.
    • Assess for atrial fibrillation and other arrhythmias — for more information, see the CKS topic on Atrial fibrillation.
  • Give all people with suspected TIA and their family/carers information on the recognition of stroke and TIA and advise them to call 999 immediately if symptoms occur.
    • Patient information is available from the stroke association website at. 
  • Advise the person not to drive until they have been seen by a specialist (when definitive guidance will be given).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to refer a person with suspected TIA are based on the clinical guidelines Stroke and transient ischemic attack: acute and long term management [British Columbia Medical Association, 2015] and National clinical guideline for stroke (prepared by the Intercollegiate Stroke Working Party) [RCP, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles[Rothwell et al, 2007; Hankey, 2014; Sehatzadeh, 2015; Lo, 2016; Rothwell, 2016].

Refer anyone with suspected TIA urgently (without risk stratification)
  • TIA is a medical emergency — risk of recurrent stroke is up to 10% in the week following a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) or minor stroke [Rothwell, 2016]. Immediate diagnosis, secondary preventative treatment and modification of risk factors (for example carotid stenosis) are essential [Hankey, 2014; Sehatzadeh, 2015; Lo, 2016].
    • Urgent assessment in a specialist clinic ensures timely and appropriate investigation (such as brain imaging) and rapid intervention (such as antiplatelet therapy, blood pressure-lowering medication, statins, anticoagulation and carotid endarterectomy or stenting where appropriate) [Rothwell et al, 2007; Hankey, 2014; RCP, 2016].
    • A patient’s 90 day risk of stroke following TIA can be lowered from 12% to approximately 2% with investigation within 24 hours and aggressive management [British Columbia Medical Association, 2015].
    • Even with the resolution of symptoms, an infarct may have occurred — TIA is a continuum of the same disease process as a stroke [British Columbia Medical Association, 2015].
  • The Intercollegiate Stroke Working Party recommend that people with suspected TIA be assessed and diagnosed urgently without further risk stratification [Lavallee, 2007; Wardlaw, 2014] because there is a substantial risk of subsequent stroke in the days following TIA but insufficient evidence on the precision of available risk stratification tools [RCP, 2016].
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis of 18 independent cohorts (n = 10,126) reporting stroke risk within 7 days of confirmed TIA [Giles and Rothwell, 2007] found that the risk of completed stroke was much lower if emergency treatment was received in a specialist stroke service (0.9%) compared to a non-urgent setting (11.0%).
    • Current risk-stratification tools have not demonstrated an ability to identify individual patients at sufficiently low short-term risk for stroke to be used confidently [Lo, 2016].
  • Short term admission or observation of people at particularly high risk of stroke (such as a suspected cardioembolic source or carotid stenosis) or in those unable to attend for urgent review or lacking a reliable observer at home may be needed [BMJ Best Practice, 2015c].
If symptoms occurred more than a week ago refer less urgently but still to be seen within a week.
  • The Intercollegiate Working Party considers that people presenting with symptoms which have resolved more than a week ago are at lower risk [RCP, 2016].
Treatment while awaiting urgent review
  • The  Intercollegiate Working Party recommends that people whose neurological symptoms have resolved (suggesting a diagnosis of TIA rather than stroke) should be given antiplatelet treatment with aspirin immediately [RCP, 2016; Rothwell, 2016].
    • However, they state that evidence on pre-hospital management of suspected stroke or TIA is lacking and most recommendations are based on consensus opinion and accepted practice [RCP, 2016].
  • CKS did not identify any evidence on what to do when TIA occurs in a person already taking aspirin.
    • The recommendation to maintain the current aspirin dose is in line with guidance issued by the American Heart Association and American Stroke Association Council on Stroke, which is based on expert opinion [Furie et al, 2011].
    • Feedback from expert reviewers generally recommended that the current dose of aspirin should be continued in people who develop TIA and are already prescribed low-dose aspirin.
